sen.j: 佃（つくだ）は、中世日本の荘園公領制において、荘園領主や荘官・地頭らによる直営田をいう。
sen.e: Tsukuda was rice field directly managed by lord of the manors, shokan (an officer governing manor) or jito (manager and lord of manor) in shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in medieval Japan.

Tsukuda was a rice field directly managed by lord of the manors, shokan (an officer governing manor) or jito (manager and lord of manor) in shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in medieval Japan.

Tsukuda was a rice field directly managed by lord of the manors, shokan (an officer governing manor) or jito (manager and lord of manor) in shoen koryo sei (System of Public Lands and Private Estates) in medieval Japan.

sen.j: 年貢や公事の賦課が免除され、収穫物をすべて領主が収取した。
sen.e: Imposition of land tax and kuji (public duties) was exempted, and all crops were collected by the feudal lord.
Imposition of land tax and kuji (public duties) was exempted, and all crops were collected by the feudal lord.
Imposition of land tax and kuji (public duties) was exempted, and all crops were collected by the feudal lord.

sen.j: 正作・用作・手作・門田とも。
sen.e: It is also known as shosaku, yujaku, tesaku, and monden.
sen.cmt: 門田：読み方確認できず
sen.e: It is also known as shosaku, yujaku, tesaku, and monden.
It is also known as shosaku, yujaku, tesaku, and monden.

sen.j: 本家・領家など上級領主による直営田を佃とし、荘官・地頭など下級領主によるものを正作・用作として区分することもある。
sen.e: The rice field directly managed by upper class feudal lords, such as head family and ryoke, may be called tsukuda while rice field directly managed by lower class feudal lords, such as shokan and jito, may be called shosaku and yujaku to differentiate.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Rice fields directly managed by upper class feudal lords, such as head family and ryoke, may be called tsukuda while rice fields directly managed by lower class feudal lords, such as shokan and jito, may be called shosaku and yujaku to differentiate.

Rice fields directly managed by upper class feudal lords, such as head family and ryoke, may be called tsukuda while rice fields directly managed by lower class feudal lords, such as shokan and jito, may be called shosaku and yujaku to differentiate.

sen.j: しかし中世当時は必ずしも明確に区分されていたわけではなかった。
sen.e: However, they were not exactly classified in medieval age.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, they were not exactly classified in medieval age.
However, they were not exactly classified in medieval age.

sen.j: 佃は耕作の形態によって大きく2つに類型化される。
sen.e: Tsukuda may be divided into two broad types based on cultivation styles.
Tsukuda may be divided into two broad types based on cultivation styles.
Tsukuda may be divided into two broad types based on cultivation styles.

sen.j: 一つは、領主が荘園・国衙領内の百姓を夫役と称して徴発する。
sen.e: The first type was that a feudal lord requisitioned peasants in a manor or a Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) as a compulsory service.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The first type was that where a feudal lord requisitioned peasants in a manor or a Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) as a compulsory service.
The first type was that where a feudal lord requisitioned peasants in a manor or a Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) as a compulsory service.

sen.j: 食糧や農具・種子を給付して百姓に農地を耕作させるものである。
sen.e: The feudal lord granted food, farm implements and seeds to peasants and made them cultivate the farmland.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The feudal lord granted food, farm implements and seeds to peasants and made them cultivate the farmland.
The feudal lord granted food, farm implements and seeds to peasants and made them cultivate the farmland.

sen.j: これらの農地はもともと領主が百姓を使役して荒地を開墾したものであり、古代末期・中世当時、荒地を開墾した者には該当地の収穫をすべて収取する権利が認められる場合が多かった。
sen.e: Such farmland was originally cultivated by the feudal lord using peasants as labor force, and those who cultivated wasteland were usually permitted the right to collect all the crops of the applicable ground in the end of ancient times and medieval times.

Such farmland was originally cultivated by the feudal lord using peasants as a labor force, and those who cultivated wasteland were usually permitted the right to collect all the crops of the applicable ground in the end of ancient times and medieval times.

Such farmland was originally cultivated by the feudal lord using peasants as a labor force, and those who cultivated wasteland were usually permitted the right to collect all the crops of the applicable ground in the end of ancient times and medieval times.

sen.j: こうして領主は所領の一部に全収穫を収取しうる田地佃を形成したのである。
sen.e: In this way, the feudal lord had made the rice field from which they could collect all the crops, i.e., the tsukuda, within their territory.
In this way, the feudal lord made rice fields from which they could collect all the crops, i.e., the tsukuda, within their territory.
In this way, the feudal lord made rice fields from which they could collect all the crops, i.e., the tsukuda, within their territory.

sen.j: もう一つの類型は、荘官・地頭などが下人・所従といった隷属民に耕作させるものである。
sen.e: The other type of tsukuda was that shokan,jito, et al. used subordinate people, such as low ranked people and shoju (retainers), to cultivate the land.
The other type of tsukuda was that of shokan, jito, et al. which used subordinate people, such as low ranked people and shoju (retainers), to cultivate the land.
The other type of tsukuda was that of shokan, jito, et al. which used subordinate people, such as low ranked people and shoju (retainers), to cultivate the land.

sen.j: 荘官・地頭はもともと直営田を持っておらず、屋敷地のみが自由に処分しうる土地として認められていた。
sen.e: From the beginning, shokan and jito did not have directly managed rice field, and they were allowed only the residential area at their disposition.
From the beginning, shokan and jito did not have directly managed rice fields, and they were allowed only the residential area at their disposition.
From the beginning, shokan and jito did not have directly managed rice fields, and they were allowed only the residential area at their disposition.

sen.j: そこで荘官・地頭らは屋敷地の周辺の農地を屋敷地の一部と称して、自己の直営田に組み込んでいった。
sen.e: Therefore, shokan, jito, et al. started to have their own directly managed rice field claiming the surrounding farmland as a part of their residential area.
Therefore, shokan, jito, et al. started to have their own directly managed rice fields claiming the surrounding farmland as a part of their residential area.
Therefore, shokan, jito, et al. started to have their own directly managed rice fields claiming the surrounding farmland as a part of their residential area.

sen.j: そして徐々に直営田の範囲を拡げていったのである。
sen.e: Then, they had gradually extended their rice field.
Then, they had gradually extended their rice field.
Then, they had gradually extended their rice field.

sen.j: 荘官・地頭らによる直営田の拡大は、特に地頭の動きが著しかったが、上級領主の荘園管理権を侵害するものであった。
sen.e: The expansion of the directly managed rice field by shokan, jito, et al., especially jito, might violate upper-class feudal lord's supervisory authority on manor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The expansion of the directly managed rice fields by shokan, jito, et al., especially jito, might violate the upper-class feudal lord's supervisory authority on the manor.
The expansion of the directly managed rice fields by shokan, jito, et al., especially jito, might violate the upper-class feudal lord's supervisory authority on the manor.

sen.j: 上級領主も当然こうした動きに対抗し、鎌倉時代後期から室町時代にかけて、両者間の紛争が頻発した。
sen.e: Naturally the upper-class feudal lord confronted such a movement, and the dispute between them occurred frequently from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Naturally the upper-class feudal lord confronted such a movement, and the dispute between them occurred frequently from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period.
Naturally the upper-class feudal lord confronted such a movement, and the dispute between them occurred frequently from the late Kamakura period to the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 佃は日本各地で形成され、佃という地名も各地に多数残存している。
sen.e: Tsukuda had been created in all over Japan, and many places named Tsukuda still remains in various places.
Tsukuda had been created all over Japan, and many places named Tsukuda still remain in various places.
Tsukuda had been created all over Japan, and many places named Tsukuda still remain in various places.

sen.j: 摂津国にあった佃 (大阪市)は中世の佃を起源としている。
sen.e: Tsukuda in Settsu Province (Osaka City) was originated in tsukuda of medieval times.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tsukuda in Settsu Province (Osaka City) originated from tsukuda of medieval times.
Tsukuda in Settsu Province (Osaka City) originated from tsukuda of medieval times.

sen.j: 佃村の漁民が移住した江戸の埋立地は佃島と名付けられ、現代に至っている。
sen.e: The reclaimed land in Edo where the fishermen of Tsukuda Villedge migrated has been called Tsukuda-jima Island down to the present.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The reclaimed land in Edo where the fishermen of Tsukuda Village migrated has been called Tsukuda-jima Island even presently.
The reclaimed land in Edo where the fishermen of Tsukuda Village migrated has been called Tsukuda-jima Island even presently.
